Why APIs?

Outline (Why APIs?)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. Why APIs? [5]
  3. Why Platforms? [8]
  4. The API Journey [9]
    1. Journey Essentials [4]
    2. Strategic API Focus [3]
    3. From Vision to Value [2]
  5. Conclusions [1]
Why APIs? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(6) APIs are more than Technology

  • Clean separation of what and how
    • APIs define what to use as network-level interfaces
    • APIs do not define how these interfaces are implemented
  • Technically, an API defines how to interact with a capability
    • Messages sent across a network that allow applications to communicate
    • The API is the interface and provides access to a product [APIs Deliver Value [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VNwAYyfQ8Bw&list=UUDD75qoXHJSz4pv0o3WcTUw] (1)]
    • Applications can collaborate using the API language [What is an API? It's a Language! [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wDYeU2T4v2o&list=UUDD75qoXHJSz4pv0o3WcTUw] (1)]
    • APIs are a promise [What is an API? It's a Promise! [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gFu7CQKmBeQ&list=UUDD75qoXHJSz4pv0o3WcTUw] (1)] to make capabilities accessible
  • The goal of APIs is to establish loose coupling between various teams
    • APIs allow machines to communicate
    • Developers document/read APIs and can start collaborating (DX)
    • Users benefit from faster time-to-value for new products (UX)


Why APIs? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(7) APIs Deliver Value [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VNwAYyfQ8Bw&list=UUDD75qoXHJSz4pv0o3WcTUw]



Why APIs? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(8) What is an API? It's a Language! [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wDYeU2T4v2o&list=UUDD75qoXHJSz4pv0o3WcTUw]



Why APIs? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(9) What is an API? It's a Promise! [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gFu7CQKmBeQ&list=UUDD75qoXHJSz4pv0o3WcTUw]



Why APIs? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(10) Necessary but not Sufficient

  • APIs have been used for many decades
    • Local APIs have been used since the 1940s
    • Network APIs have been used since the 1950s
    • Network APIs used to be called Protocols
    • APIs are relatively new as an approach for Enterprise IT Architecture
  • APIs deliver most benefit when used for loose coupling
    1. Others (partners/public) can easily access APIs for collaboration
    2. Internal collaboration becomes easier (less coordination overhead)
    3. Mixed deployments are a natural architectural pattern with APIs
    4. Platform business models can leverage APIs for value co-creation


Why Platforms?

Why Platforms? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(12) The World is Changing Faster

  • Existing value chains may be challenged and must adapt
  • Global connectivity enables new opportunities to scale
  • A networked economy creates many network effects
  • Changing markets require changes in products and value propositions


Why Platforms? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(13) Linear Business Models



Why Platforms? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(14) Platforms are Eating the World

  • Platforms businesses are taking over many markets
  • Platforms facilitate value exchanges
  • Platforms scale well
  • Platforms are using the network effect
  • Platforms are a lesson in thinking beyond the linear model


Why Platforms? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(15) The Platform Business Model



Why Platforms? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(16) Platform Types

  • Platform business models come in two flavors
  • Exchange platforms facilitate exchanges of existing value
    • Value is transferred and often limited in supply by producers
    • The core transaction often has to be made as frictionless as possible
  • Maker platforms support creation of value on the platform
    • Value is exposed and often unlimited in supply
    • The core transaction often is designed to improve value creation/consumption


Why Platforms? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(17) But … We're not Google

  • Pure platforms are more the exception than the norm
  • Linear business models can be augmented with platform ideas
  • Creating hybrid models can make a big difference
    • Opportunity to scale because the platform part attracts consumers
    • Ability to differentiate in an increasingly commoditized market
    • Decreasing risk because of more feedback and ability to adapt


Why Platforms? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(18) Hybrid Linear/Platform Business Models



Why Platforms? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(19) A Cautionary Tale

  • Many organizations are adding social features to their products/experiences
  • Protecting against trolling, spam, and harassment is important
  • Building robust social protections is not trivial
  • Organizations end up with dependencies in their value chains

Journey Essentials Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(22) Start Small

  • Identify low-hanging fruit for quick success and feedback
    • API Archaeology [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=67FTcwtxYIs&list=UUDD75qoXHJSz4pv0o3WcTUw] is a good way to find candidates
  • Switch from building systems to cultivating ecosystems
    • Focus on constraints (what to do) over rules (how to do it)
    • Only govern when you must (autonomy) and not when you can (authority)
  • Start building a culture and a community
    • API Guidelines should reflect the lived reality in an organization


Journey Essentials Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(23) Design for Change

  • Ecosystem architecture and system architecture are distinct disciplines
    • APIs allow you to start building a landscape of API products
    • How to build API products is a different and distinct task
  • The role of ecosystem architecture is to support development teams
    • Constrain them as much as necessary but as little as possible
    • Cleanly separate constraints from how to implement them
    • Provide support for following constraints and testing for them
  • Always ask yourself how much effort it is to change course
    • Good ecosystem architecture scales over size and time and change frequency


Journey Essentials Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(24) Cultivate the Landscape

  • Be clear on your vision and strategy
  • Start with small and focused effort and teams
  • Build up competencies and ways to share them across teams
  • Shift from centralized systems to decentralized ecosystems


Journey Essentials Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(25) Scaling is not Easy

(27) Two Common API Goals



Strategic API Focus Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(28) Scenario 1: Engaging in the API Economy

  • Direct API monetization
  • API foundation for user journeys (omni-channel)
  • Value chain optimization (outsourced APIs)


Strategic API Focus Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(29) Scenario 2: APIs for Modular Architecture

  • Moving from integration to interconnection (IT modernization)
  • Decoupling products and their development cycles and speed
  • Improving capability reuse across the whole organization

(31) Mind the Gap



From Vision to Value Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(32) API Strategy = Pillars × Perspectives

External Internal
Biz
  • API monetization
  • Revenue-supporting APIs
  • Increase speed & feedback
  • Identify & stabilize enablers
  • Design for externalization
  • Increase biz insight with dashboards
Org
  • Focus on documentation/DX
  • Support discovery/self-service
  • Collect DX feedback
  • Products > projects (ownership)
  • Team enablement/support
  • Loose coupling for speed/agility
Tech
  • Tech trends and popularity
  • Invest in on-boarding support
  • Secure through platform
  • Loosely coupled implementations
  • Observe patterns and practices
  • Establish C4E for platform/support
